messages: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:44): notes that <email/> would be much easier to use if it put the commit message in the email subject line
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:44): send mail asking for it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:44): i make no promises
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (01:47): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: you think so too?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:47): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: fwiw, messages to <email/> do have a truncated version of commit message in the subject line
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:47): http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-diffs/2008Jun/
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:48): It's somewhat amusing that Bjoern suggests catering to stone-age mail clients on a list dedicated to creating the future :)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:48): the body of the message links back to the whatwg HTML5 webapps-tracker
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:48): as well as to other things
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:52): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Ah, that's close to what I'm wanting
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:52): But I can't trust anything that's not hosted on whatwg.org ;-)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:55): worries that Philip has seen right through his mind-control experiment
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:56): man, this really has got to be the quote of the day]
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:56): "With the exception of the cross-burning episode. ... I believe John Freshwater is teaching the values of the parents in the Mount Vernon school district."
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:56): http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5g1SluWTuZ9ddhhJI06SSqutTwstgD91E38D00
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:57): I could argue that I want to use commit-watchers instead of public-html-diffs because I want to minimise the number of clicks needed to see the diff
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:57): so it's better when the diff is directly in the email

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (01:59): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Although from the same article... "he was certified only in science, the report said"... nice to know he was sane except in matters of science :)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (01:59): Oh and ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c's suggestion sounds very useful
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:03): Maybe it was a chemistry experiment
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:06): Oops, I misread the "Giant reorg to move things ..." commit message as "Giant robot to ..."
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:07): I do hope science fiction's predictions of giant robots will come true, because they'd be awesome
c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1 (02:22): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, it seems unlikely that they'll look like robots
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:39): The successful ones will be those that are marketed well, and awesome-looking giant robots are much easier to sell than boring metal boxes
c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1 (02:40): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, well, we sort of already have giant robots... modern jet airplanes for instance
c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1 (02:40): what would you do with a gigantic metal humanoid?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:41): I would crush my opponents
c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1 (02:41): my opponents are all on the internet
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:41): Also it would make a nice garden decoration
c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1 (02:41): i wouldn't know where to find them to crush them
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:41): c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1: You could ask them
c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1 (02:41): i giant botnet would far cooler
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:41): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea : http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-diffs/2008Jun/0162.html
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:42): or just look them up on Facebook to find their home address
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:42): +1 to giant robots
c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1 (02:43): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, i guess you were a big fan of that transformers movie then
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:43): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Hmm, you are doing a good job at tempting me to switch my diff provider :-(
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:44): c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1: Actually I've never seen it (except for trailers)
c4c52ee28b65ac033f57ce478087cfd1 (02:44): i thought it was pretty stupid, but it did have huge robots.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:45): I tend not to watch any movie unless I see it for ¬£5 while I happen to be walking through a DVD store
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:45): (Sometimes I stretch to ¬£5.99)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:46): I find trying to read through non-syntax highlighted diffs it plain-text e-mail to be not so great a way of reviewing them
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:46): but I will admit that's the main way I initially read most diffs myself
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:47): I guess it's good enough for doing a first-pass look-through to see if you care to go look at in more detail
